Fig 4 Oxygen evolution over Fe1/NiSe2 single-atom electrocatalyst: The role of thermal-electrical cascade and surface reconstruing Ju Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Supervision Software Investigation Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ Yusheng Liu Investigation Data curation a Zhaoxu Wang Software Resources Formal analysis b Jia Wang Validation Software Formal analysis c Wenyou Zhu Software Methodology Funding acquisition a Wenchang Zhuang Validation Project administration a Lin Tian Visualization Software Resources Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Materials and Chemical Engineering, Xuzhou University of Technology, Xuzhou, Jiangsu, 221018, China School of Materials and Chemical Engineering Xuzhou University of Technology Xuzhou Jiangsu 221018 China aSchool of Materials and Chemical Engineering, Xuzhou University of Technology, Xuzhou, Jiangsu, 221018, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University of Science and Technology, Xiangtan, Hunan, 411201, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hunan University of Science and Technology Xiangtan Hunan 411201 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University of Science and Technology, Xiangtan, Hunan, 411201, China c School of Health Science and Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China School of Health Science and Engineering University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai 200093 China cSchool of Health Science and Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water electrolysis is a tough challenge. Here we report the thermally activated on-surface oxygen evolution at nickel diselenide under alkaline conditions, specifically focusing on the (101) and (100) facets supported with Fe single-atom electrocatalysts. Assisted by heat, the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets demonstrate highly efficient activity for oxygen evolution at pH = 14. First-principles calculations and AIMD simulations illustrate excellent electrical conductivity and thermal stability of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets, as well as provide a promising understanding of electron transports among the oxygen-containing active species and the electrocatalysts during thermal-electrical cascade of OER under alkaline conditions. The enhanced OER performance depends on the co-adsorbate combinations: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) and *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Ni) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, whose adsorption behaviors lead to self-activated surface reconstruing. Impressively, the affinity of the key intermediates at the potential-determining steps of OER: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, *O(Fe) and *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, is optimized by such self-activated surface reconstruing. Graphical abstract Assisted by thermal catalysis, nickel diselenide supported with Fe single-atom catalysts, specifically the (101) or (100) facet, exhibits highly efficient activity for oxygen evolution under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Single-atom electrocatalysts Thermal-electrical cascade Effect of surface reconstruing DFT calculations Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Thermal-electrical cascade opened a new scene on optimizing oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance and developing highly efficient electrocatalysts [1-5]. Experimental and theoretical studies were focused on designing thermal-electrical cascade processes and unraveling the dependence of the true active species in OER and the dynamic electrocatalysts’ surface structures [6,7]. For instance, the OER efficiency on iron-benzene hexathiol coordination polymer increased dramatically when assisted by the thermal catalysis processes, even outperforming IrO2 and RuO2 catalysts at 80 °C [8]. Highly efficient alkaline OER activity on the carbon nanowires combined with palladium-cerium nanoparticles can be obtained using the electrospinning-thermal carbonation approaches [9]. Benefiting from the thermoelectric effect of the air electrodes, the breathing Zn-air batteries were further developed by using the P-type Ca3Co4O9 and N-type CaMnO3 thermo-electrocatalysts in the dual air electrodes configurations [10]. Moreover, Lakhanlal et al. revealed that heat treatment on NiFeOOH-based aerogels at 150 °C resulted in the decreased work function within the catalyst and promoted the significant improvement on OER catalytic activity [11]. The enhanced OER activity is due in large part to the tunable electronic structures of the electrocatalysts and dynamic surface refiguration via interfacial engineering during thermal-electrical cascade [12,13]. The electrocatalysts constructed by interfacial engineering contribute to the modifications of their density of states and Fermi energy levels, thus enhancing the cohesion between two components, reducing the leaching of metal ions, and boosting their adsorption and OER catalytic activities [14,15]. Li and Feng et al. reported interfacial engineering of Ru-doped Co3O4/CoP nanowires heterostructures as efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for alkaline water splitting [16]. For overall water splitting, it only required an ultra-low cell voltage of 1.66 V to operate the current density of 20 mA cm–2 by using Ru-Co3O4/CoP/TM as both the cathode and the anode [16]. Tan and Pan et al. proposed cationic oxidative leaching engineering modulated In Situ self-reconstruction of nickel sulfide for superior water oxidation [17,18]. Furthermore, a nitrate ion tailed strategy was developed to mitigate Fe segregation and improved the OER stability of nickel-iron catalyst [19]. However, it remains to be disclosed the true active sites, electron transports among the active species and the catalysts, especially the mechanism of dynamic surface reconstruing in OER process under acid and alkaline conditions, respectively [20,21]. It also presents a formidable challenge to experimental characterizations and DFT theoretical calculations. Configuring interfacial engineering and probing surface restructuring behaviors are needed urgently for developing highly efficient electrocatalysts for OER. Nickel selenide is an alternative approach for addressing the bottleneck in high overpotential and sluggish kinetics [22-24]. It has the advantages of unique spatial configuration, tunable electronic structures, high-density state of d-electrons and high covalent degree of metal-anion bonding, as well as the disadvantages of insufficient adsorption and desorption capacity for oxygen-containing species during OER processes under alkaline conditions [25,26]. Improving the electron density of the Ni sites is essential to enhance the OER catalytic activity of nickel selenide. In this work, we used the introduction of Fe single-atom electrocatalysts and thermal-electrical cascade to improve the electron density of the Ni sites in pristine nickel diselenide, promote surface reconstruing, and aim at more-than-optimal activity for OER under alkaline conditions. Assisted by thermal catalysis, nickel diselenide supported with Fe single-atom catalysts, specifically the (101) and (100) facets, demonstrates highly efficient activity for oxygen evolution under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). First-principles calculations and AIMD simulations reveal that the enhanced OER performance depends on the thermal co-adsorbate combinations, whose adsorption behaviors contribute to the modifications of the electrocatalysts’ density of states and Fermi energy levels, leading to the self-activated surface reconstruing. The affinity of the key intermediates at the potential-determining steps of OER, such as *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, *O(Fe) and *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, is optimized by such a self-activated surface reconstruing. This work underscores the importance of understanding electron transports among the active species and the catalysts and provides valuable insights for the exploration of high-performance electrocatalysts via combining interfacial engineering and thermal-electrical cascade. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Computational methods All the DFT calculations were carried out using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [27,28]. The exchange-correlation energies were calculated through the Perdew-Becke-Ernzerh functional and the generalized gradient approximation [29]. Ionic cores deficiency was described by the projector augmented wave pseudopotentials [30-36]. The cutoff energy was 400 eV. The convergences of energy and force calculations were 10-5 eV and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. K-points within structural optimization calculations were set as 2 × 3 × 1 and 3 × 3 × 1 for the M1/NiSe2(101) and M1/NiSe2(100) facets, respectively, while 5 × 5 × 1 sampling was used for the M1/NiSe2(101) and M1/NiSe2(100) facets within the spin-polarized density of states calculations. Gaussian smearing with a width of σ = 0.05 eV was carried out. The van der Waals interactions were considered by the Grimme (DFT+D3) method [37-39]. The transition states were identified using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [40,41]. The implicit solvation models were taken into consideration using VASPsol to identify the solute-water solvent interactions during thermal-electrical cascade of OER processes under alkaline conditions [42]. The d-band centers of the d-states of the catalysts were located after the spin-up and spin-down d-states calculations. In addition, we conducted ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations in the NVT canonical ensembles with the Nose-Hoover thermostats employed at 300, 500, 800, and 1000 K, respectively [43,44]. The total time and the time step for the AIMD simulations were 10 ps, and 1.0 fs, respectively. Adsorption energies (Eads ) of possible intermediates at the different facets of the electrocatalysts during oxygen reduction were carried out by the formula: Eads = E(adsorbate/slab) –E(slab) –E(adsorbate) [45,46]. Energy barrier (Ea ) was conducted by the formula: Ea= E(TS)-E(R) [47,48]. Electron localization function (ELF) [49,50] was performed by the formula: E L F = ( 1 + χ σ 2 ) − 1 . The positive ELF values indicate that the bonds are dominated by bonding orbitals. The changes in Gibbs free energy of each fundamental step during OER catalytic processes under alkaline conditions were calculated using the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) approaches: Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S − e U R H E , which avoided the determination of the solvation energies of the protons [51-53]. The electrode potential e U R H E can be calculated from the format: e U R H E = e U S H E − k B T l n a H + = e U S H E + k B × p H × l n 10 , where a H + is the activity of the H + ions in solution. To derive Gibbs free energies of bonding or adsorption, zero-point energies and entropy corrections were approached using VASPKIT codes [54]. 2.2 Catalyst models Single-atom electrocatalysts were modeled by the six-atom layers (144 atoms) in 2 × 2 periodic slabs of the NiSe2(101) and (100) facets, respectively. A surface Ni atom at the NiSe2(101) and (100) facets was replaced by a dopant atom M (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Os, Ir, Pt, Au), respectively, as well as different doping positions were considered. The top three layers of the single-atom electrocatalyst slabs were fully relaxed, while the other three ones were fixed in the bulk positions. The vacuum gap was 20 Å to avoid the neighboring slabs interactions. Initial configurations within ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were obtained from the optimized DFT geometries. The SAC formation energy: H f S A C = E S A C − E s u r f − ( E b u l k N i − E b u l k M ) , reflects the possibility that a dopant atom institutes the Ni site at the exposed NiSe2(101) and (100) facets [55,56]. E S A C , E s u r f , E b u l k N i , and E b u l k M are the energies of the M1/NiSe2(101) or (100) facet, the NiSe2(101) or (100) facet, the bulk Ni, and the bulk foreign metal M, respectively. The substitutional M1/NiSe2(101) and M1/NiSe2(100) facets (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ru, Rh, Os, Ir, Pt) demonstrated energetically favorable, as shown in Figures S1 and S2. Especially, the SAC formation energy Hf for the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and Fe1/NiSe2(100) facets were -5.53 and -5.21 eV, respectively. Among the stable M1/NiSe2(101) facets, the OER overpotential from the lowest to the highest under alkaline conditions (pH = 14) was Fe, Co, Mn, Ru, Rh, Os, Pt, and Ir, respectively. Meanwhile, that among the M1/NiSe2(100) facets was Fe, Co, Ru, Mn, Rh, Os, Ir, and Pt, respectively. Introduction of Fe single-atom electrocatalysts upon the NiSe2(101) and (100) facets demonstrated the most competitive candidates for the highly efficient OER electrocatalysis under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). More details were supplied in Table S1 of the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Heat-enhanced OER at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet under alkaline conditions The Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet is one of the most favorable among all the possible candidates for OER under alkaline conditions (in Fig. 1 , S1 and Table S1), as well as its SAC formation energy, potential-limiting (LP) barrier, and overpotential at pH = 14 is -5.53 eV, 0.98 eV and 0.58 V, respectively. The substitutional Fe at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet relates to four neighboring Se atoms via four Fe−Se bonds (Fe−SeⅠ, Fe−SeⅡ, Fe−SeⅢ, and Fe−SeⅣ), as well as the ELF values and the lengths being 0.65 |e|, 2.226, 2.241, 2.201, and 2.251 Å, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1 and S3. The Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet has excellent electrical conductivity and thermal stability. Its electronic states cross the Fermi level, and no obvious structural distortions or deformations are observed after 10000-step's AIMD simulations at 300, 500, 800, and 1000 K, respectively. The OH radical adsorption at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet is the first step of the OER process under alkaline conditions (pH = 14), accompanied by the formation of the intermediate *OH(Fe) and a potential increase of 0.33 eV. When the OH radical adsorbs on the Fe active site of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, the 2p orbitals of oxygen in the *OH(Fe) active specie overlap with Fe-3d orbitals of catalyst (in Fig. 2 ). Electrons would transfer from oxygen of *OH(Fe) to the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet to form the O−Fe bond. As shown in Tables S2 and S3, the length and ELF value of the O−Fe bond in the *OH(Fe) active specie are 1.877 Å and 0.10 |e|, respectively. Fe d-band center of the catalyst is -1.41 eV, as well as adsorption energy of *OH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet being -1.54 eV. *OH(Fe) then reacts with the second hydroxyl group at pH = 14 to form one H2O molecule and the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) intermediate which is adsorbed onto Fe and SeⅠ atoms of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet. This process requires a small potential increase of 0.11 eV. Nevertheless, adsorption energy of *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ), the key intermediate in OER, is as much as -1.85 eV. It presents the hardest challenge to the subsequent *OOH(Fe) production that requires a potential increase of as 0.98 eV. Electronic structure results in Figs. 2, S4, S5, and S6 identify electrons transfer between the oxygen-containing species and the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet under alkaline conditions and further provide valuable insights for the associated OER electrochemical mechanism. Our findings reveal that the 2p orbitals of oxygen in *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) overlap with Fe-3d orbitals and SeⅠ-4p orbitals of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet. Electrons would transfer from oxygen of *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) to the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet through the delocalized O−Fe−SeⅠ interactions around oxygen of *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ), surface Fe and SeⅠ atoms of the catalyst. The delocalized O−Fe−SeⅠ interactions in *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) are the formidable obstacles for *OOH(Fe) production at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet. Among them, the length of the O−SeⅠ bond is 1.837 Å, as well as its ELF value being 0.13 |e|, indicating that O−SeⅠ bond in *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) breaks difficultly during *OOH(Fe) production. The length and ELF value of the O−Fe bond in the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) active specie are 1.841 Å and 0.08 |e|, respectively. Metal Fe d-band center of the catalyst is -1.38 eV. And finally, *OOH(Fe) reacts with the fourth hydroxyl group in the alkaline solution to form one H2O molecule and one O2 molecule, accompanied by a potential increase of 0.18 eV. Impressively, *OOH(Fe) production under alkaline conditions can be facilitated by the thermally activated co-adsorbates: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) combined with *OH(Se Ⅱ ) and *OH(Ni), respectively. The essential increase of potential from the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) intermediate to the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) combination is 0.41 eV. Thermal catalysis then proceeds on the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) combination and produces the intermediate *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, accompanied by a low activation barrier of 0.68 eV. Excellent stability of the catalyst is also favorable for *OOH(Fe) production under alkaline conditions. Correspondingly, the potential-limiting (LP) barrier of *OOH(Fe) production at pH = 14 is reduced to 0.41 eV via the thermally activated combination: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) and *OH(Se Ⅱ ) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet. The thermal *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) combination leads to a self-activated surface reconstruing that is favorable for the cleavage of O−SeⅠ bond in the *O(Fe_Se Ⅰ ) active specie, further promoting the active sites’ conversion of the catalyst during *OOH(Fe) production. In the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) combination, the length of O−SeⅠ bond is 1.868 Å, as well as its ELF values being 0.05 |e|; the length and the ELF value of the O−SeⅡ bond is 1.844 Å, and 0.043 |e|, respectively. Metal Fe d-band center of the catalyst is -1.52 eV, shifted downwards than that of -1.38 eV in the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) intermediate. Altogether, these further illustrate that the affinity of the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) active specie at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet can be optimized by combing with the *OH(Se Ⅱ ) active specie, as well as its reduced adsorption energy being -1.36 eV. On the other hand, dual Fe-SeⅠ active sites in the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) intermediate converse to single Fe one in the *OOH(Fe) intermediate more easily. The potential requirement for *OOH(Fe) production is significantly lowered to 0.41 eV. Thermal catalysis can also proceed on the *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Ni) combination and produce the *OOH(Fe) intermediate at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet under alkaline conditions, accompanied by a low activation barrier of 0.63 eV. The potential requirement for *OOH(Fe) production can be significantly lowered to 0.43 eV. As presented in Fig. 2, clear charge transfer within the reduced O−SeⅠ bond (the ELF value: 0.04 |e|), electron delocalization around oxygen atoms of *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) and surface Fe, SeⅠ atoms, as well as the downshifted Fe d-band center of the catalyst can occur. It suggests that assisted by heat, the OH(Ni) active specie at the Ni site of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet can be captured by *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) easily, which contributes to the modification of their density of states and Fermi energy levels of the electrocatalysts, further leading to the optimized affinity of the key intermediate *O(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet. The low barrier of 0.63 eV at the thermal catalysis step: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) + *OH(Ni)→*OOH(Fe), and excellent stability of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet also facilitate *OOH(Fe) production and enhance OER performance under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). 3.2 Heat-enhanced OER at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions As shown in Figs. 3 , S2, S7, S8 and Table S1, OER processes occur at single Fe active sites of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions (pH = 14), produces *OH(Fe), *O(Fe), and *OOH(Fe) intermediates subsequently, and finally releases an O2 molecule away. The Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet has excellent electrical conductivity and thermal stability, as well as its SAC formation energy, potential-limiting (LP) barrier, and overpotential at pH = 14 is -5.21 eV, 1.07 eV and 0.67 V, respectively. Each substitutional Fe relates to four neighboring Se atoms of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet through four Fe−Se bonds. The ELF value and the lengths of Fe−Se bonds (Fe−SeⅤ, Fe−SeⅥ, Fe−SeⅦ, and Fe−SeⅧ) are 0.58 |e|, 2.201, 2.294, 2.374, and 2.228 Å, respectively. The electronic states of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet cross the Fermi level, and no obvious structural distortions or deformations are observed after 10000-step AIMD simulations at 300, 500, 800, and 1000 K, respectively. The OH radical adsorbs at single Fe active site of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet firstly, accompanied by the *OH(Fe) formation and the potential decrease of 0.44 eV. The next formation of the *O(Fe) intermediate needs a small potential increase of 0.05 eV, indicating that O−H bond in *OH(Fe) breaks quite easily. Nevertheless, the Gibbs free energy requirements for *OOH(Fe) production and O2 desorption are as much as 0.92 and 1.07 eV, respectively, which presents the two hardest challenges for the OER processes at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). Impressively, the exciting part is that *OOH(Fe) production at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet can be facilitated by the co-adsorbates: *O(Fe) combined with *OH(Se Ⅴ ). As presented in Figs. 3 and S8, the essential increase of potential from the *O(Fe) intermediate to the *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination is 0.51 eV. Thermal catalysis proceeds on the *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination and produces the intermediate *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, accompanied by a low activation barrier of 0.49 eV. The potential-limiting barrier of *OOH(Fe) production at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions (pH = 14) can be lowered to 0.51 eV via thermally activated combinations: *O(Fe) and *OH(Se Ⅴ ). The *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination induces Fe d-band centers of the catalyst shifted downwards and leads to a self-activated surface reconstruing. As shown in Figs. 4 S9, and S10, Fe d-band center of the catalyst within the *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination is reduced to -2.59 eV, as well as adsorption energy of the *O(Fe) active specie at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet being -1.56 eV. Such a self-activated surface reconstruing boosts electron transport between the *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination and the electrocatalyst. The ELF value of O−Fe bond within the *O(Fe)-*OH(Se Ⅴ ) combination is 0.09 |e|, respectively. By contrast, those in the *OH(Fe), *O(Fe), and *OOH(Fe) intermediates during OER under alkaline conditions (in Tables S4 and S5) are about 0.14, 0.12, and 0.11 |e|, as well as their adsorption energies at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet are -2.31, -2.01, and -1.87 eV, respectively. It suggests that assisted by heat, the *OH(Se Ⅴ ) active specie can be captured by *O(Fe) at the Fe site of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet easily, which contributes to the modification of their density of states and Fermi energy levels of the electrocatalysts, further optimizing the affinity of *O(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet. In addition, the thermal-catalysis process: *O(Fe) + *OH(Se Ⅴ ) → *OOH(Fe) only requires a low activation barrier of 0.68 eV. However, the hydroxyl group at the Ni sites of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, *OH(Ni), can be captured by the *O(Fe) group at the Fe sites with a few possibilities, which requires an activation barrier of 1.73 eV to produce *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet. O−H bond in the *OOH(Fe) intermediate then breaks and H transfers to the SeⅧ site of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet. This process leads to the *OO(Fe)-*H(Se Ⅷ ) combination at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). The potential increase from the *OOH(Fe) intermediate to the *OO(Fe)-*H(Se Ⅷ ) combination is 0.76 eV. Assisted by heat, the O−Fe bond in the *OO(Fe) active specie breaks and an O2 molecule releases from the surface. The thermal-catalysis process: *OO(Fe) →O2(g), requires a low activation barrier of 0.51 eV. And finally, the *H(Se Ⅷ ) active specie reacts with the hydroxyl group in the alkaline conditions to produce a H2O molecule. During O2 desorption at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet under alkaline conditions, the self-activated surface reconstruing occurs, which promotes electron transfer between the *OO(Fe)-*H(Se Ⅷ ) combination and the catalyst. The length and the ELF value of O−Fe bond in the *OO(Fe) active specie (in Tables S4 and S5) is 1.796 Å and 0.05 |e|, respectively, reduced than those in the *OH(Fe), *O(Fe), and *OOH(Fe) intermediates. H−SeⅧ bond in the *H(Se Ⅷ ) active specie is weak, as well as its ELF value being 0.03 |e|. Fe d-band center of the catalyst is -2.71 eV. Excellent thermal stability of the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet during OER thermal-electrical cascade is also beneficial to *OOH(Fe) production and O2 desorption under alkaline conditions (pH = 14). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have demonstrated the highly efficient activity of Fe single-atom electrocatalysts supported by nickel diselenide for OER under alkaline conditions (pH = 14), specially their Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets. First-principles calculations and AIMD simulations reveal excellent electrical conductivity and thermal stability of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets, as well as electron transports among the active species and the electrocatalysts in OER. The enhanced OER performance depends on the co-adsorbate combinations during thermal-electrical cascade of OER processes: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) and *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Ni) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, whose adsorption behaviors could lead to self-activated surface reconstruing. The affinity of the key intermediates at the potential-determining steps of OER, such as *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, *O(Fe) and *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, is optimized by such a self-activated surface reconstruing. Additionally, *OOH(Fe) production at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet can be facilitated by the thermally activated *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) and *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Ni) combinations, respectively. High potential requirement of *OOH(Fe) production and O2 desorption at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet can also be reduced by the thermocatalytic processes: *O(Fe) + *OH(Se Ⅴ ) → *OOH(Fe) and *OO(Fe) → O2(g), respectively. This work provides a promising understanding of electron transports among the active species and the electrocatalysts in OER and offers valuable insights for the exploration of high-performance electrocatalysts through combining interfacial engineering and thermal-electrical cascade. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water electrolysis is a tough challenge. Here we report the thermally activated on-surface oxygen evolution at nickel diselenide under alkaline conditions, specifically focusing on the (101) and (100) facets supported with Fe single-atom electrocatalysts. Assisted by heat, the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets demonstrate highly efficient activity for oxygen evolution at pH = 14. First-principles calculations and AIMD simulations illustrate excellent electrical conductivity and thermal stability of the Fe1/NiSe2(101) and (100) facets, as well as provide a promising understanding of electron transports among the oxygen-containing active species and the electrocatalysts during thermal-electrical cascade of OER under alkaline conditions. The enhanced OER performance depends on the co-adsorbate combinations: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Se Ⅱ ) and *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ )-*OH(Ni) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, whose adsorption behaviors lead to self-activated surface reconstruing. Impressively, the affinity of the key intermediates at the potential-determining steps of OER: *O(Fe-Se Ⅰ ) at the Fe1/NiSe2(101) facet, *O(Fe) and *OOH(Fe) at the Fe1/NiSe2(100) facet, is optimized by such self-activated surface reconstruing.
